scenes.location: EMPTY LOT NEAR DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES
characters: LUCKY TO STEP IN MY BEAUTIFUL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights of downtown L.A. twinkle in the distance. PETE KLAVEN, late 20s-early 30s, nice looking, approachable, stands in front of a fenced in lot with his attractive girlfriend, ZOOEY RICE, same age, a little artsier-lookin

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So, my plan is to build a cluster of live-work lofts around the perimeter here, and then create this really neighborhoody retail and dining area in the central square here. I even thought maybe you and Hailey and Denise could open up another location of your store.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Really? Denise keeps talking about wanting to open another branch.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It'd be great. The land is a little pricey, so, I won’t be able to develop it right away, but, when I sell the Ferrigno Estate, I figured out, I’1ll at least be able to put a down payment on it, and still have enough money left over for the reception in Santa Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter, what are you talking about? What reception? Beat. Peter pulls a small JEWELRY BOX from his blazer. A look of realization washes over Zooey’s face.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know it’s only been eight months, but, I am madly, insanely, ridiculously in love with you. He opens the box, revealing a lovely DIAMOND ENGAGEMENT R

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you marry me? Off her look of complete, utter happiness...  INT. PETER’S CAR - NIGHT Peter drives. Zooey is in the passenger seat, glowing. Sh speaks over the car’s BLUETOOTH SPEAKERPHONE with one of two best friends, HAILEY.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: ...it just happened like two minutes ago. Hailey, can you believe it?!

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How have I been on like ten million dates and you end up marrying some totally awesome guy who randomly walks into our store?!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Peter) Doesn’t realize she’s on speaker... (into car microphone) Will you conference in Denise?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold on. Zooey grabs Peter’s hand as she waits...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: That piece of land is perfect.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m so excited you like it. The neighborhood is like, two years away from taking off, but-- DENISE, Zooey’s other best friend, comes on the line.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I cannot fucking believe you didn’t call me first.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You are such a freak! Hailey’s before you in my speed dial!

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m kidding. Zooey, oh my god! I am so psyched for you it is disgusting. Hold on, Barry goes crazy if I’m in the house during his poker night. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her husband) Give me a second you fat douchebag. Zooey just got engaged. Peter. You’ve met him twenty times, dum- dum. (into phone) Sorry, Zo. So, did you guys pick a date?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: June 30th in Santa Barbara. Peter already booked that place Bacara where we went for that long weekend.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, he is so sweet. Wait, is Bacara the one where you guys slept together for the first time?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, wasn’t that in the hot tub in Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s right. It was Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You told them about the hot tub?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wow, so June 30th?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s soon, but--

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who cares? Peter’s a doll, and he goes down on you six nights a week. What the hell are you waiting for? Peter looks at Zooey in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You’re right. It’s gonna be great. I gotta go. I’11 call you later. Love you.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Love you! So fucking psyched for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do they know so much about our sex life?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Hailey and Denise are my best friends in the world. Girls share stuff like that. As Peter considers this...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah! We're engaged! I’m so excited! She kisses him passionately, as we go to... EXT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Hand in hand, Zooey and Peter walk towards their cozy bungalow in the Silverlake section of L.A.. Zooey’s on he cell-phone.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: ..--I know, he’s the best. I feel so lucky. (quietly, to Peter) It’s Debbie. She’s freaking out. (back to phone) Alright, I gotta call Lisa, call me later, okay? Love you, bye. They enter the house. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT It’s decorated in a minimalist way with cool, eclectic furniture and knickknacks. Zooey is on the phone with another friend.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: .--love you too, Lisa. Talk to you tomorrow. She hangs up. Turns to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sweetie, I’m totally hogging the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that’s fine. I just want to give my parents a call.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Peter speaks with his mom, JOYCE, on speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: .--Mom, what do you think she said?! She said yes!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, I’m so thrilled for you. And you did it in front of that piece of land like we talked about?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, she loved it. Thanks, that was such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that was her idea. Thank you, Joyce! In the b.g., the sound of MEN EXULTING.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dad sounds really excited. You told him?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Actually, he and Robbie are watching some kind of boxing program. Peter’s father, OSWALD “OZ” KLAVEN shouts out...

dialogues.speaker: OZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ultimate Fighting!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do they want to get on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sure. Hold on, honey. (after a moment) Apparently, they’re in the middle of the game, sweetheart. But they say congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. No prob. Alright, well, we'll talk to you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Bye, Joyce!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kids... I’m thrilled. Goodnight. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Was that weird that your dad and brother didn’t want to pick up?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I’m sure they’1l call back. Wow, I am exhausted. Getting engaged is intense. You want to go up to bed?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: It’s only nine. You don’t want to call any of your friends?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nah, I’1l make some calls tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Really? You don’t want to call that guy Tevin? Don’t you speak like twenty times a day?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, he’s more like a co- worker than a friend.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Or Gil, from your fencing club?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He’s not really a ‘Call right away to tell him the news’ kind of friend.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: So, who do you consider your closest friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, you know there’s a bunch of guys. Samir Patel, my freshman roommate from UCLA.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I’ve never heard you mention him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No? One Beer Samir? We’re pretty tight. You’re right, I should give him a ring.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Peter’s on the phone. Zooey putters around in the b.g., pretending not to be paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, Samir? It’s Peter... Peter Klaven. Yeah, man, I guess it’s been a little while. You been good? Great, well, I just wanted you to know that I got engaged tonight, so, we’re getting married in three months and... Samir, no, I didn’t bail on your wedding, I just, I couldn’t make it. I thought I sent a gift though... no? Oh, well... I’m sorry, man. I didn’t know you were so... okay, right, you take care as well. He hangs up. Looks at Zooey.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: When’s the last time you spoke to him?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I guess it was a couple years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you go to his wedding?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I wanted to, but, I promised Lindsay I'd go to her family reunion that weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: And he’s your closest friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s... no, I have a bunch of good friends. I have the guys from my fencing club. There’s Bob Loden.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Your chiropractor?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He’s a great guy. Honestly, I think Samir has a drinking problem. He must've forgotten how close we were. (off her skeptical look) Don’t look at me like that. I have friends. Just ‘cause they don’t call me every two seconds like Hailey and Denise, doesn’t mean they don’t exist. EXT. PETER’S PARENTS’ (THE KLAVEN’S) HOUSE - NIGHT Peter and Zooey stand at the front door. JOYCE KLAVEN, hugs Peter. Then Zooey. Ad libs her congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Where’s Dad?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: In the den. Robbie gave him this Nintendo Wee or Wah, who knows what, for Father’s Day. They’re obsessed. (shouting) Boys, Peter and Zooey are here!

dialogues.speaker: 0Z, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Out in a minute! I’m about to kick your son’s ass in Tiger Woods! INT. THE KLAVEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 50s, Peter and Zooey sit around the dining room table with Joy Peter’s soft-spoken but macho, guy’s-guy father, OZ, as w as his cute, gay younger brother, ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: ...did Peter have any good friends growing up? She looks to Oz, who shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I honestly don’t seem to remember any.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Zooey, just to clarify here, Dad worked for IBM. We moved every eighteen months.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Robbie always managed to have friends. I mean, he probably wanted to suck their dicks, but--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oswald!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Mom, he’s actually kind of got a point.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Well, he still doesn’t need to use that language. The point is, Zooey, Peter always connected with women.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I can see that. He’s a great boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Also, you need to remember that he matured sexually at a very young age. I remember taking him swimming when he was twelve, the kid had a bush like a forty year old Serbian.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dad, please stop speaking.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: No, but, you always had a girlfriend, as far back as I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: He wasn’t a guy’s guy. Your brother here is into video games, fishing, we golf together...  10.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? I play sports.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You prance around in tights with a sword. It’s not a sport.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, snap!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m a competitive fencer. It’s in the Olympic Games!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Oz, you two didn’t do father-son stuff together when Peter was a kid?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Almost never. He spent all his time hanging out with his mother or circling real estate listings.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was nurturing an interest that became my career.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: A woman's career.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: There’s plenty of male real estate agents.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: It’s just something of a faggoty job, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “Faggoty?!” You can’t use that word!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes, I can. Robbie gave me permission.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Dad loves the gays. I made him an honorary homo last week.  11.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Guys, this is ridiculous. Why is it weird that I had girlfriends?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: We're just saying you never had a best friend. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who’s your best friend?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I have two. Hank Mardukas has been my closest friend in the world since our first year at IBM, he was Best Man at my wedding, we speak three times a week for the past thirty years. And then, there’s Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Robbie is your other best friend?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Correct. And Hank Mardukas.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Zooey, here’s the deal. Peter’s a girlfriend guy. Okay? Girlfriend guy’s never have good male friends because they put all their energy into their girlfriends so their male friendships fall by the wayside.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Zooey, don’t listen to him. Robbie barely knows me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Peter, I happen to be an expert on men, and I know it’s true. We are who we are.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Well put, son. We are who we are. Look, you think I was happy when Robbie told us he was a flamer? Of course not, but, I got used to the idea that he craved a wiener in his caboose after about five minutes, and the truth is he’s cool as hell.  12.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Dad, I actually prefer to be the top.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I know you do, pal, I’m speaking metaphorically here.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Alright, that’s enough. Come on, let’s clear the table. Peter stands up to help his mom.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t help Mom with the dishes?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Do you see Robbie and me lifting a finger? (points to him and Robbie) Guy’s guys. Peter looks very unhappy. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT The newly engaged couple get ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You know what? I completely forgot. I do have a best friend.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Who’s that, sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter, I’m your girlfriend--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fiance.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Fiance, whatever. I don’t want to be your best friend. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t get me wrong... I love you. It’s just different.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don’t feel like you can be open and honest with me? I thought we talk about everything.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: We talk about almost everything. There’s just certain things I talk about with Hailey and Denise that I could never... it’s just different, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I don’t have any close male friends. So, do you not want to marry me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Of course not. I really don’t care. I just want you to be happy, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m very happy. It’s not like this is something I’ve been missing. Peter takes a ZANTAC from a bottle on his night-table Swallows it with some water.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? Your acid reflux?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A little bit. It’s fine. They get into bed.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I’m just thinking, for the ceremony, I want a bunch of Bridesmaids up there, plus my Maid of Honor...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: But if I have six girls standing with me, and you don’t have anyone, it might seem a bit uneven, no? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you thinking Robbie might be your Best Man?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Robbie? No. Like I said, we’re really not close.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You know what, don’t worry about it. We'll figure something out. (then) Oooh, it’s my turn to host Ladies Night tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No prob. I have fencing practice. I‘ll go for a drink with the guys afterwards. (realizing) I’m telling you, those dudes are my friends.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I know, baby. They start kissing. Things are heating up, when... the ph rings. Zooey turns on her bedside light, picks up the pho eyeing the Caller I.D..

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Hailey. She had a blind date. I‘ll be two seconds. I just want to make sure she’s okay. INT./EXT. PETER’S CAR - MORNING As Peter drives to work, through the car windows, he take a world of MALE FRIENDSHIP he never noticed before. -He sees a group of CONSTRUCTION WORKERS laughing. -FOUR SUIT-WEARING GUYS gabbing away as they carpool. -Two JOCKS jogging together. -A BILLBOARD with two SWEATY BUDDIES, post-workout chuggi an ENERGY DRINK. -A cluster of OLD RUSSIAN MEN playing CHESS and KIBITZING an outdoor café.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typical real estate office. Filled primarily with WOMEN

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN AREA
dialogues.text: Peter fixes a coffee as he speaks to a few FEMALE CO-WORK

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ...she was completely surprised. It was really, even more amazing than I thought it would be.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Oh, Peter, that’s so romantic.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Just.. congratulations. So happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Ooh, I’m so jealous. You’re gonna be the best husband!

dialogues.speaker: MAIN OFFICE AREA
dialogues.text: As Peter heads towards his desk, he passes the cubicle of handsome, cheesy guy named TEVIN DOWNEY -- perma-tan, blo streaks in his hair. He is cracking up from something on computer when he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What’s so funny?

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: One of the guys in my fantasy football league sent me a Quicktime of a grandma riding a Sybian machine.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: It’s a vibrating saddle that women sit on to give them super-intense orgasms. Check this out. Peter looks at the monitor. And winces.  16.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How sick is that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Very. That is very sick.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: So, what up, Dog? How’s the Ferrigno dealio coming?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Coming good. Getting ready for the Open House in a couple weeks.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: It’s a big piece of house, so, if you want a co-pilot on this one, let me know, okay? Be happy to team up, help you “Git R Done.”

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What does that mean, “Git R Done?”

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Larry the Cable Guy? The hilarious comedian?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I don’t really know his stuff. Anyway, I think I got it under control, but thanks for the offer. Tevin goes back to his computer. Peter takes a final glan at the sick image on the screen, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two MEN, dressed in fencing gear, expertly parry with eac other. They finish, remove their masks, revealing that on of them is Peter. They salute each other, as fencers do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A post-shower Peter and some other FENCERS get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: FENCER
dialogues.text: Nice job stealing my tempo there, Peter.  17.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I set you up for a solid attack on the blade, but you parried back pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: FENCER
dialogues.text: Anybody seen my Manchette?

dialogues.speaker: FENCER
dialogues.text: Under your Plastron, dickweed. They jostle with each other -- the way men do in a locker room. Another fencer, GIL, talks to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: I told my cousin the open house is a week from Saturday, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s gonna be great. I appreciate you hooking me up with him, Gil. It’s a really big deal for me.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: You sold me my house, right? You're the most honest real estate agent I know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thanks. And look, I know you’re the middle-man here, but, if your cousin has any questions, he should feel free to call me.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: I will let him know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Great. So, you guys want to get some grub? Or, grab a beer or something? The fencers exchange uncomfortable looks.

dialogues.speaker: FENCER
dialogues.text: We're actually, uh, we’re driving up to Joshua Tree tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? What’s going on up there?  18.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: (jostles Fencer #1) We're taking Eugene on a little bachelor party slash camping trip.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you’re getting married.

dialogues.speaker: FENCER
dialogues.text: I am, indeed. Next Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Great. Cool deal. You doing kind of a small thing, or--

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Um, it’s like three... twenty five. I managed to rope these boys into being my groomsmen.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Very, very cool. Awkward beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: I would've invited you, but, you never really come out with us after practice. I didn’t think you--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dude, don’t sweat it. Seriously, no worries. It’s funny, I just got engaged myself.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: That’s great, Peter. Your fiance designs book jackets, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, that was Heather, she was a couple of girlfriends ago. Zooey owns a home furnishing store in Silverlake.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Awesome, man. Good luck with that.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: Alright, we have a long drive. We should hit the road. Later, Peter.  19.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Have fun, boys. Peter waves, watches them exit -- joking with each other. sits there alone in the locker room, sadly packing up. EXT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Peter is about to enter through the front door. Through t window, he sees Zooey and her GIRLFRIENDS sitting around living room, drinking wine, laughing. He heads to the back of the house. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - BACK DOOR - NIGHT Peter quietly lets himself in. INT. PETER’S HOME OFFICE - NIGHT Peter is on his computer. ON THE SCREEN -- he works on th online listing for a spectacular, MODERN HOUSE in the Hollywood Hills. He fiddles with the layout and descripti The sound of female laughter is audible O.S.. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT Peter prepares a tray of ROOT BEER FLOATS for the ladies. he does, he looks out the kitchen window, sees his MALE NEIGHBOR in his house across the way -- watching a BASKET GAME with his FRIENDS. They all react as Kobe dunks. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS Zooey hangs out with a circle of LADIES, including HAILEY single and miserable about it, and DENISE, caustic and married.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: He didn’t make any friends at UCLA?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: He lived alone after freshman year.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Ooh. The ones who lived alone we're always the biggest freakazoids.  20.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter’s not a freakazoid. He had a serious girlfriend all through college.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Look, we’re not saying he’s a freakazoid, but the truth is, for the future of your marriage, it’s a little troubling. If Barry didn’t have any friends I’d shoot myself in the face. The ladies laugh. BY THE DOOR TO THE KITCHEN, Peter is ab to interrupt when he just stops... and LISTENS.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m serious. You know what my favorite nights are? Hanging out with you guys. And I can do it guilt free because Barry loves hanging out with his friends too. Every month there’s a golf weekend, a ski-trip, a weekend in Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: You let him go to Vegas? Aren’t you worried he’s cheating on you?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: He’s forty pounds overweight with a Jew-fro and a small dick. (off their looks/laughter) I love the guy to death, but I’m far and away the best looking woman he’s gonna get, and I’m just a seven.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE LADIES
dialogues.text: Come on! You are so not a seven! You’re hot!

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: I know, I totally think I’m higher than a seven! I was testing you bitches!

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: So, who’s going to be his Best Man?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I have no idea. I really think his Mom might be his closest friend.  21. The ladies react to/shudder at the thought of this.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: This is a serious issue, Zo. Guys without friends can be super- clingy.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: My dad had no friends. It was awful. He dragged my mom to all these football games. She hated it. That’s a big reason why they got divorced.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Look, the truth is, I’m freaking out, you guys! I know, I’m horrible for feeling this, but, I can’t believe I’m marrying someone who has no friends! Peter motions to turn back around when he makes a noise.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peter? Peter opens the swinging door between the kitchen and the rest of the house... holding the tray of root beer floats

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, I just made you guys some Root Beer Floats. The ladies greet Peter, ad lib -- thanking him, congratulating him on the engagement. Then...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I thought you were going out with your fencing team?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, they couldn’t make it, so, I just came back here. Don’t worry, I’ve been in my office working. I’m not even here. Bye, ladies. He sets down the floats. Starts to exit.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the floats, baby. That was really sweet. He waves, disappears.  22.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit! You think he heard us?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Definitely not. The ladies all shake their heads, trying to convince themselves. INT. PETER’S HOME OFFICE —- CONTINUOUS He stares out the window, watching his neighbor say goodb to his friends -- giving half-hugs, cool handshakes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buff MEN and WOMEN enter and exit this sleek gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie Klaven wears a tight fitting tee-shirt that reads: TRAINER. He walks with a concerned looking Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You need to find a Best Man for your wedding?! What are you, ina John Hughes movie?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know, it sounds ridiculous, but, Zooey is really upset about this friend thing. You said at dinner you know all about men. I don’t know where else to turn.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: This is so exciting, you coming to me for help. The good news is, not only do I know about men, but straight guys are my specialty.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I get bored pursuing gay guys. When you’re cute and fit, you can pretty much have any fag you want. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like to set my sights on straight guys to give myself more of a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Does it work?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Peter, I get more butt-pussy from straight guys than you could ever imagine.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just... please don’t ever use that term with me again. Robbie walks up to a bench press where a GUY is strugglin with a bar-bell. Robbie adopts more of a straight-guy voi

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Come on! Push it out! It’s all you! I’m not even helping! Little further! There you go! The guy looks up at Robbie appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH PRESS GUY
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No worries. I’11 see you around.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH PRESS GUY
dialogues.text: I hope so. Robbie and the guy exchange smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That guy was totally flirting with you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I know, and did you see the wedding ring? Straight as an arrow. I’m telling you, hooking up is easy. Meeting platonic male friends, not so much.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why is that?  24.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Several reasons. First off, at your age, most men are settled into their groups of friends. Either they have friends from high school, college, or work. As time goes on, the straight ones get married, spend time with their wives and kids, even their old male friendships tend to fall off. The single guys could care less about finding new male friends unless it’s a wing-man who can help them pick up girls. So, you’ve set yourself a high bar. It can be done, but, ‘tain’t gonna be easy.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Alright, so, what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: We have to put the word out on the street that you’re available. I’11 do some recon around the gym, but you need to be aggressive about this. Every man is a potential suitor. You see a guy on the street, strike up a conversation. Ask him on a man-date. By that, I mean a casual lunch or after-work drink. No dinner and no movies. You’re not taking these guys to see THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA, understand?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes. Keep it casual.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Men are very sensitive about meeting new friends. Why? Because they’re all secretly afraid that they’re gay, and half of them are. So, they overcompensate by being emotionally distant and guarded. An incredibly STRAIGHT-SEEMING GUY walks by, exchanges “Hey’s” with Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Let me guess, you slept with that guy?  25.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, but he gave me a handjob in the steam room last week. It was terrible, ‘cause his fingers were all calloused from weightlifting.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: See, this is why we don’t hang out. You're disgusting. Robbie shrugs, unfazed. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Peter and Zooey sit on the living room couch watching the last scene of BRIDGET JONES’S DIARY.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How is it that Renee Zellwegger is from Texas? Her accent is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I know, it’s crazy. Oh my god, Colin Firth’s sweater--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ooh, so painful.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Way to put this on your Netflix cue, baby. Peter walks to the TV, ejects the DVD.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So, I know this might sound weird, but I’m going to try to meet someone before the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A friend. So, if you, or any of your zillion girlfriends have any candidates, I just want you to know, I’m available.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You’re so ridiculous. You're going to try and meet a friend?  26.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why not? I want a Best Man up there with me. I don’t want to look like a big loser when you have twenty eight bridesmaids, and I can’t even get One Beer Samir to show up on my end.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I know you’re just doing this for me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, I really love you, so, it kind of feels good.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I am so happy you walked into our store that day. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You wanna try and do it before Hailey gets home from her new date?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Shut up, jerk. (then) She’1ll be back in a few minutes, so it’s gonna have to be a quickie. And as they start taking off their clothes, we FADE UP A and begin a montage of Peter’s man-dates. We see the set- ups, and the dates in a series of SPLIT-SCREENS AND JUMPC INT. BARRY AND DENISE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Denise talks quietly to her husband, BARRY, in the doorwa Behind them, Peter sits at a poker table with BARRY’S ASS FRIENDS.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: The guy has no idea how to play poker!

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Barry, this is important to Zooey, so shut the fuck up and be nice.  27.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Only if we can have sex with the lights on when you get home.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Love you.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is talking to his female co-workers...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: .»+.so if you know any available men, just feel free to give ‘em my number, or E-mail if that’s easier.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER FEMALE CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: I have the perfect person! Peter, please take my husband off my hands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Peter valets his car, we hear his MOM talking in V.O..

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Honey, he just moved to L.A.. Barely knows anyone. He’s an architect. His mother says he’s so excited to meet you. Peter waves to an attractive guy, DOUG, waiting outside. guy mouths, ‘Peter?’ Peter nods, they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie talks to a CLIENT as he helps him with a lat pull- down.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: .«..my brother’s a great guy, fun to be around. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I‘1l give you five free sessions if you go out with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter watches a basketball game with Robbie’s gym client, we now realize has A VERY HIGH VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH VOICED GUY
dialogues.text: Pass the goddamn rock, you piece of shit! He’s so selfish, you know?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He really is.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH VOICED GUY
dialogues.text: What is your problem, Zebra?! That was a foul! Peter is clearly embarrassed to be with the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter eats an Early Bird Special with an OLD MAN who stud the chocolate drink in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: The perfect Egg Cream is two parts seltzer water, one part whole milk, and then, and pay attention here, one part U-Bet Chocolate Syrup. No other brand will suffice, you understand me? Peter nods, trying to hide his boredom. INT. BARRY AND DENISE’S HOUSE - NIGHT The poker game is in progress. Peter pushes his CHIPS int the middle.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I guess I’m all in. Is that how you say it?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Yes, Peter, that is how you say it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m sure you beat me. I just have five of the same suit or whatever.  29. Barry looks like he’s ready to kill Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Doug, the attractive guy, are hitting it off as they share a bottle of wine, getting a little tipsy. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - HOME OFFICE - NIGHT As Peter works on the website for the Ferrigno Estate, he looks out his window, sees his neighbor now hosting a backyard barbecue with his buddies. Peter GOOGLES: ‘How do you meet straight male friends?’. His eyes land on a site called “MEET-NEW-FRIENDS.COM.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The high-voiced guy is chanting at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH VOICED GUY
dialogues.text: LET’S GO... LAKERS! LET’S GO

dialogues.speaker: LAKERS
dialogues.text: Peter winces, covers his ears in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man has FALLEN ASLEEP at the table. Peter gently wipes DROOL from his mouth with his napkin. INT. BARRY AND DENISE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Barry and his friends play a drinking game called BOAT RA - where you must chug a beer then tap the guy next to you chugs as well, until one team finishes first. On his team, Peter gets tapped, starts CHUGGING his beer, until he gags and THROWS UP all over the GUY next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Doug exit, hand their tickets to the VALET.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I gotta tell you, I really enjoyed this, Doug. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been out with so many jerks, it’s great to finally meet someone I can have an actual conversation with.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Let’s do it again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night? Matsuhisa. Eight o'clock? The Valet pulls up in Doug's car.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I will see you there, sir. Peter starts to extend his hand, when Doug reaches out AN KISSES PETER ON THE MOUTH. He withdraws, enters his car, leaving Peter standing there, stunned. INT. PETER’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Peter is on speakerphone with his mom.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He put his tongue in my goddamn mouth, Mom!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How could I know he was gay?! All Rita said was her son wanted to meet my son!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And you didn’t think for a minute that she was talking about your son who sleeps with men?!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was one kiss. I don’t know why you’re so upset?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You know why I’m upset?! (beat, then) Because I really liked him! He's terrific!  31. INT. PETER’S HOME OFFICE - NIGHT Peter is chatting with a man named LESTER on “MEET-NEW- FRIENDS.COM.” Lester types in the three most exciting wor in any online relationship: “SHOULD WE MEET?” Peter’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous Peter enters, scans the room for his friend. He eyes several POTENTIAL CANDIDATES, when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: LESTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter? Peter turns, sees an ELEVEN YEAR OLD KID wearing Harry Po glasses and a pointy Wizard’s hat with stars and moons on

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Lester? Confused, Peter approaches Lester’s table, when... BEHIND HIM -- Lester’s square-jawed father, BUTCH, runs u Peter, puts him in a choke-hold.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahh!!!

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Stay away from my son, sicko!!! Other PATRONS and EMPLOYEES start to notice the scene. Pe tries to speak while Butch chokes him...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He said he was thirty eight! I just wanted to meet a friend!

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: He’s eleven years old, you freakin’ pedophile You think I don’t read his e-mails?!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: But, Dad--

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Stay out of this, Lester! (to Peter) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You contact my son again, pervert, I will murder you where you live! And with that, Butch tosses Peter out of the Starbucks. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT The couple lie in bed, reading design magazines. Peter's neck is swollen and red.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: How’s your neck?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not bad. Still a little tender. Zooey, I’m sorry, this friend thing obviously isn’t working out.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I kind of figured that. Denise said you threw up all over Barry's poker buddies.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Because they made me play this stupid drinking game. That’s exactly why I wasn’t ina fraternity. Look, I tried. I just don’t think I’m going to find a Best Man by June 30th.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Honey, it’s okay. You can’t just manufacture a good friend.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I mean, I can go on some more man- dates, but, I have the Open House this weekend...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter, forget it. Seriously, I don’t care. Just please, stay off the internet. It’s a horrible way to meet people. You should talk to Hailey about it sometime. Beat. Then, Peter shakes his head...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He said he was thirty eight.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even more impressive than it looked on the website. An OP HOUSE SIGN with Peter’s name is prominent on the front la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the MOVIE POSTERS and MEMORABILIA, it is clear that house belongs to Lou FERRIGNO, the hearing-impaired body- builder/actor who starred in the film PUMPING IRON, and, TV, as THE INCREDIBLE HULK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Peter set up for the Open House. -He places a stack of INFORMATION SHEETS on a table by th front door. -He unwraps a platter of SMALL DELI SANDWICHES on an isla in the kitchen. -He straightens up the furniture. -He lights some candles. -He opens shades, letting golden sunlight in. -He puts Norah Jones on the stereo system. -VARIOUS PROSPECTIVE BUYERS enter. Peter chats them up, tours them around the place.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE FOOD TABLE
dialogues.text: SYDNEY FIFE, late 20s-early 30s, takes out the turkey fro one sandwich, adds it to the corned beef from another sandwich, creating a double-decker. Sydney has a casual, slightly unkempt appearance. He watches Peter talking to a YOUNG HOLLYWOOD GUY and his GIRLFRIEND. The Hollywood guy nods, tells Peter they’re going to look around on their own. Peter walks up to the food table.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thank you for eating.  34.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m the first one, huh? I don’t know why people are so afraid of chowing down at an Open House. (beat) So, how come Ferrigno’s selling?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He bought a place in Jackson Hole. I think he’s tired of the Hollywood grind.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It’s a great pad. I’m not sure I'd keep the Pumping Iron posters, but--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (chuckling) No, the place will come empty. I’m Peter Klaven, the realtor.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sydney Fife.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (points to the Hollywood couple) You were wasting your time with those two, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I saw that guy pulling in. He drives a Volkswagon Passat. That's a thirty thousand dollar car, and he’s looking at a 4.3 million dollar house? Doesn’t compute. He hasn’t been dating the girl he’s with for more than two weeks, maybe three. In fact, from their body language, I doubt he’s slept with her yet. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, he tells her he’s looking for a new house, brings her along, hoping to impress her, which he might, ‘cause she doesn’t look like the sharpest monkey in the monkey house, then he’1l sleep with her at her rental in Toluca Lake, go back to his one bedroom in Studio City, having done nothing but gotten laid while wasting your valuable time.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Wow. He told me he was going to make me an offer. I really hope you’re not right about that. The Hollywood guy passes Peter on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOLLYWOOD GUY
dialogues.text: You know what, guy, I like it, but I’m thinking it’s just a little small. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Me, I’m going tell you right up front, I have no intention of buying this house whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Uh, okay, so, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pete, I am here, on a beautiful Saturday afternoon, to eat your free food and try to pick up a divorcee. Peter laughs, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Are you serious?  36.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Iam. At the classier Open Houses, the spread is usually delicious, plus, aside from the poser douchebags like the dude who just left, you normally get a delightful panoply of financially solvent, newly single women.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What can I say? I appreciate your honesty, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Is there anymore Russian Dressing? Peter stares at Sydney - ‘Is this guy for real?’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men replenish the bowl of Russian Dressing.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: .-.I do private investments. Manage my own portfolio. It’s great. I work from home, keep my own hours.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And you can make a living doing that?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m not exactly flying private, but yeah, I do nicely. The thing I ask myself, is, can I afford my lifestyle? If the answer is yes, I’m happy. The Europeans have it right... they work to live, not the other way around. I tend to adhere to a more Continental way of thinking.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’re right, in America, you’re considered lazy if you don’t work a sixty hour week.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You ever been to Italy?  37.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I took a trip there with my ex- girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: So, you know... those people enjoy their lives way more than we do over here.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I gotta say, they did seem pretty happy. The bowl of Russian Dressing has been filled.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Alright, man, I’m gonna fix myself another sammy, then I have an Open House in Bel Air that promises to be replete with Cougars. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look, here’s my card. If you ever need a place, I actually specialize in smaller homes, bungalows--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sounds good. Here, you might as well take mine too. They exchange cards. Peter eyes Sydney’s, which reads: SYDNEY FIFE INVESTMENTS, LLC. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for a great Open House, Pete. Peter watches Sydney exit, clearly intrigued by this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is holding down the legs of one of his CLIENTS whi he does crunches as Peter talks to him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t just call him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be such a pussy. He gave you his card. Of course you can.  The sound is awful.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And say what? ‘Oh, hey, Sydney, you want to get dinner with me?’ I hate this. There’s no rules for male friendships.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What is the big deal? You went out with all those other guys?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Those were set-ups. This is completely different.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Fine, then wait around for him to call. And if he does, no more dinners, okay? It’s sending the wrong message.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know. Actually, that guy, Doug who kissed me, he’s really great. You want his number?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, he’s gay. I told you, I’m not into that. The High-Voiced Guy spots them across the gym.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH VOICED GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, Peter. lLakers/Mavs tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can’t do it. I have... a thing. (turns to Robbie) By the way, I can’t thank you enough for setting me up with that Castrato. It was really fun.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH VOICED GUY
dialogues.text: Come on, push it out! It’s all you, baby! Yeaahhhh!!! 38. Shouts out.. ON HIGH VOICED GUY, giving a BENCH-PRESSER a spot. Robbie looks at Peter contritely.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits at his desk, staring at Sydney’s card. He pick up the phone, hangs up before he dials.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just... pathetic. We JUMP-CUT to, Peter dialing. He gets Sydney’s VOICEMAIL

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is Sydney Fife. You know what to do. Peter affects a business-like tone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hi, Sydney, this is Peter Klaven. We met at an Open House last week. Anyway, I was just checking in, seeing if you wanted to get together, talk about real estate or whatnot. So, if you get a chance, give me a call. No pressure. Okay, take care. Bye-bye. EXT. “ZHD” STORE — DAY Establishing of this cool-looking home furnishing store o trendy street in L.A.’s Silverlake neighborhood. INT. “ZHD” — CONTINUOUS The store is filled with modern furniture, housewares, knickknacks and art. Zooey, Hailey and Denise sit around the checkout counter, eating salads, listening to Hailey tell a story.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: «+.SO, we go back to his house. We're kissing. It’s getting a little heated, I’m like, ‘Okay, I’m gonna have sex for the first time in three months. That’s cool.’ Then, he rolls over, opens a drawer in his night-table... proceeds to pull out a huge strap-on dildo.  40.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: What’s the deal, he’s a pre-op tranny?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: No, he is a man, and what he asks me to do, in a very casual tone, is, strap on the fake penis, and, uh, screw him with it, in his butt.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: By the way, you may not be into that, but, I don’t think it necessarily makes him gay.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: It was a first date, Denise! Who requests that on a first date?! Peter enters the store.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Hey! What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was downtown meeting with the owner of my development site. Thought I’d say hi on my way back to the office.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You just missed Hailey telling us how a guy she met on J-Date wanted her to do him with a strap-on.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: So, that was my Wednesday night. How's your man-search coming?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: About the same as yours. It’s tough, there’s not a lot of great men out there.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Barry said he and his friends had a good time with you the other night.  41.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Really?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: No. I guess you took all their money and threw up on them. Peter’s cell-phone rings. He steps away, answers it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Peter Klaven... yes, right, Sydney. Good to hear from you. This afternoon? Uh, yeah, sure, I can do that. Father’s Office at 5. See you in a jiff. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: See you in a jiff?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know. I’ve never said that expression in my life.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Baby, you’re all flustered. Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This guy I met at my Open House, Sydney something....

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Oh my god! Peter’s gota boyfriend!

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: This is insane! How did you get a boyfriend before me?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t have a boyfriend. We're just grabbing a drink. Talking about real estate.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Don’t forget, we’re having dinner with Denise and Barry and Debbie and Max.  42.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yup. Edendale Grill at 8.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Guys, what the hell?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: You can’t make a dinner plan without me. We have an unspoken pact about stuff like this.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: It’s a boring couple’s dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Oh, so, because I’m single, I suddenly have the Ebola Virus. Peter quietly watches these friends interact...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You don’t have Ebola, we just didn’t think you’d want to come.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: I’m your best friend. You don’t think I’d at least want to know?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: I thought I’m your best friend?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Zooey and I have been best friends since sixth grade. We didn’t meet you till college, and you weren't even undergrad with us.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: So fucking what?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Guys, this is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, which one of us is your best friend?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I love you both. I’m not gonna choose.  43.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Well, you can’t have two Maids of Honor, so, at some point, you'll have to decide.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (quietly) I’m gonna take off.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: (waves, then, to Hailey) Why don’t you just come to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: I can’t. I’m going out with the strap on guy. (off their looks) What? We had a really nice time, until he asked me to fuck him in the ass with a rubber dick. EXT. FATHER’S OFFICE RESTAURANT - DUSK Peter’s on his cell phone as he walks into this famous Sa Monica gourmet beer and burger pub.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m meeting him right now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter, play it cool, okay? No dinner. You don’t want him to think you’re easy.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, I promise, no dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ooh, this is exciting! Call me when you get home! INT. FATHER’S OFFICE RESTAURANT - DUSK Peter and Sydney sit at a table drinking pints of beer.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: So why’d you call it quits with your last girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Lindsay? We were right there on the marriage track, but, then I found out she was a kleptomaniac.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Oof. Those are the worst.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, she shoplifted from stores, from my parents’ house. One time we went to Disneyland with her nephews, she got busted for stealing a case of Mickey Mouse golf balls.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: She was a golfer?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A golfer? No, you’re missing the point. She was a thief.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, I get it. I’ve just always wondered if having a girlfriend who could join you for eighteen would be a blessing or a curse. Anyway, go on...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right, so, when it started getting really out of control, I called it off, and, I literally met Zooey the day after we split up.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Really? No laj in between the vag?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You didn’t have any lag time between women?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn’t plan it that way, but, it just happened. Zooey’s super smart, we’re both really into architecture, home design. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I swear, we can make an entire night out of, like, going through the photos in the latest issue of Metropolitan Home.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: How's the sex?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You’re going to be making love to one woman for the rest of your life. So, is it good?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s kind of private, you know?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Not really. It’s something we all think about on a minute by minute basis, but, we’re not supposed to talk about it? Why? Beat. Peter thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’re right. I guess, no one’s ever asked me the question, that’s all. The sex is good. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Your voice when up when you said that.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It means, you weren't being entirely truthful. What’s the deal?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I guess at times, I wish she enjoyed, you know...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Getting in it the tush?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?! No. Oral sex.  46.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t like it when you go down on her?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, that she likes. It’s the other way, she doesn’t seem to... what am I doing? Sydney, I barely know you. Look, Zooey’s an awesome woman, we have a great sex life. I don’t know why I said that.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you're speaking honestly.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What about you? Are you single? Married?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Iwas. I got devoed a year ago. We started out great, but, Leanne got too needy. Never gave me my space. I finally said ‘enough.’

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Divorce sounds really tough.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It was rough for a while, but, the truth is, Pistol, I’ve never been happier.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What does that mean, ‘Pistol?’

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pete Maravich. Great basketball player. Nickname was The Pistol. A YOUNG COUPLE hovers over their table -- as is tradition this restaurant where you have to fight for a seat.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GUY IN COUPLE
dialogues.text: You guys finishing up soon?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sorry, chief, we’re actually staying for dinner. Peter’s eyes widen.  47.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, you know what, Sydney, I should get going.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude, are you serious? They literally have the best burgers in the world here. If you get a seat at Father’s Office, you do not leave without eating. Peter’s clearly considering it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Alright, screw it. I’min. Let me just call Zooey. EXT. FATHER’S OFFICE - NIGHT Peter’s on his cell.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ...we’re in the middle of something here. Just tell them I had a work emergency.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter, we made a plan.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know, but, we see those guys every week. It’s just one time. I gotta go, I'll see you later. I love you. INT. FATHER’S OFFICE - NIGHT Peter returns to the table.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: All good?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: All is good. All is good in ‘da hood. (off Sydney's weak-smile) So... As he sits, the BARTENDER puts a new song over the sound- system, and we begin a SERIES OF DISSOLVES...  48. INT. FATHER’S OFFICE RESTAURANT - NIGHT Peter and Sydney drink several more pints and eat the restaurant's gourmet hamburgers, clearly hitting it off. They crack up. Have a serious conversation. Talk heatedly It’s a GREAT FIRST MAN-DATE. EXT. FATHER’S OFFICE RESTAURANT - NIGHT Peter and Sydney stumble out of the place.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hands down, best hamburger I have ever had. I love the way they caramelize the onions.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: People say it’s the meat, but I agree, the onions set it apart.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Alright, I should grab a cab. I think I’m over the legal limit.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude, you only had like three pints. You’ll be fine. My Vespa blew a tire on the way over. You mind giving me a ride home? INT. PETER’S CAR - NIGHT Peter drives. Sydney rides shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How could you hate Salman Rushdie?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: The guy’s a phony. Had you ever heard of him before The Satanic Verses?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, but--  49.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Butt cheeks. He was a struggling novelist who wrote a book that he knew was gonna drive the Ayatollah crazy, get him a ton of publicity in the process, and sure enough, the guy puts a fatwa on his head. Next thing you know, he’s an international celebrity, writing songs with Bono, he marries the hot chick from Top Chef, lives like a king in some four star London hotel... on the government’s dime.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (cracking up) So you’re saying he wanted the death threat on his life?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Wanted it? The man loved every goddamn minute of that fatwa. I guarantee you, he begged the Ayatollah not to take the price off his head. A SIREN behind them flashes onto their car.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh shit! Sydney, this is bad, I’m sure I’m over the legal limit.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Stay calm and let me do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, don’t say anything! You have a breath mint or a piece of gum?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Peter, relax, it’s gonna be okay. Peter pulls the car over. A COP approaches.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You have any idea how fast you were going?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I am so sorry, sir. I thought was under the Speed Limit.  50.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Actually, you were going forty three in a twenty five M.P.H. zone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Got it. Whatever you need to do, write me a ticket, anything. I just want to make things right. The cop picks up on Peter’s overcompensating. Sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You gentlemen been drinking this evening?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, we have, friend.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: We had a few pints at a bar in Santa Monica. My buddy’s wife just left him for a Mexican guy. He walked in on the two of them banging in his laundry room.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: If that’s not bad enough, she tells him she’s taking the kids, all the savings, moving down to freakin’ Guadalajara with this yag-off. So, I dragged my man out, got hima little toasted to try to balm the pain. He’s probably one drink over the limit, two-max. Beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Fucking Mexicans.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You said something there, my brother. Steal our jobs. Steal our women. Where does it end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know, friend. I do not know. Just, keep it under the speed limit, okay, fella. Hope stuff works out for you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I do too. Thanks, officer. The cop leaves. Peter turns to Sydney, exhales for the fi time in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife ran off with a Mexican guy?! Where the hell did you get that?!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: The cop had an indentation where his wedding ring used to be, so I figured the cheating spouse angle was a good bet. The Mexican part, was an assumption that he was a racist, based on his buzz-cut, vocal intonation, and general demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney, that was incredible. Disturbing, but incredible.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Just so you know, and I’m serious about this, I have no problems with Mexicans whatsoever. I was just trying to get you out of a DUI.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Got it. They resume driving.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just realized, I never asked, are you interested in buying a house?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Uh, no, why would I be?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, just when you called me back, I didn’t know if you wanted to talk real estate, or--  52.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Look, Pete, maybe this is weird to admit, but, you seemed like a good dude. I was just... seeing if you wanted to get a beer.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, there’s nothing weird about that at all. Why can’t two guys go out for a beer? I’m glad you called.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Me too. Peter looks over, they exchange a quick smile, drive on. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT In the bedroom, Zooey is sleeping. Peter tiptoes in. Zooe speaks in that half-asleep voice.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: That wasn’t nice.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Come on, Zo, we always go out with your friends. It was one time--

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I know, I just missed you. Did you have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It was fun. We mainly talked business, but, he’s a cool guy.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: So, is he your Best Man?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (laughing) I barely know him. Go to sleep, I just want to see if we got any hits on Ferrigno. PETER’S HOME OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Peter’s on the phone with Robbie, speaking quietly.  53.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter, I’ve been on pins and needles! Where the hell were you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We ended up having dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No! I told you, no dinners!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know, but he insisted. Anyway, we had a great time. He’s really interesting. He called me a nickname. “The Pistol.” No one’s ever called me a nickname before.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Listen to me. You need to play it cool. Do not call him tomorrow. Give it a day or two, okay? (to someone 0O.S.) Jump in, I'll be right there!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m taking a bath with one of my clients.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH VOICED GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Robbie, come on, I’m getting lonely.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The castrato?! That guy’s gay too?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He is now.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You are such a slut.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know. It’s retarded. I’ma total “Himbo.” I’11 call you tomorrow.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is at his desk when Tevin Downey comes over, singin his version of the old Tag Team rap “Whoomp! There It is.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Whoomp! There he is! Whoomp there he is! He grabs Peter, begins to jostle/tickle him. Peter hates this, but can’t stop from laughing.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay, man.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Whoomp! There he is!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Tevin, seriously, cut it out! I’m fucking ticklish!

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Okay, Uncle-Uncle! How was the Open Hizzy?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The Open House? It was good. I’ve had a few nibbles, no bites yet--

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Peter, can I speak to you as a friend? You're a flats guy, and the Hollywood Hills are my specialty.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: True, I’ve sold mainly in the flats, but--

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: For singles and doubles, you’re the freakin’ Ichiro Suzuki of realty. But, we’re dealing with a Hollywood celebrity here. This is the house of Mr. Louis Ferrigno. That’s rare air, my man.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you see my web-listing? It looks great.  55.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: To sell a plot like that, you gotta network, meet a lot of people, work the town. It’s what I did with Scotty Baio’s pad up on Wonderland Ave. We got her done before she even went on the market.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are you saying, Tevin?

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: You've got the steak and I’ve got the sizzle, so let’s split the listing. Let me wet my beak a little on this action and we’1ll both end up winners.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I really think I can handle this by myself.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s your call. Like I said, I’m putting on my friend hat here. Tevin gives Peter a final tickle in the ribs, walks away. Stressed, Peter takes out his bottle of Zantac, pops one. Nearby, he sees the receptionist talking to a female real who holds a HARRY POTTER book. He looks closely at the co -- a picture of Harry in his wizard garb.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER MARSH
dialogues.text: Peter’s underage internet friend, playing with a sword in backyard. He still wears the Harry Potter glasses and wizard’s hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits in the living across from Lester’s parents. Lester is visible through the window.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know, it sounds crazy, but, I never really had any close male friends so, I just wanted to meet someone.  56. BUTCH (LESTER’S DAD) Who the hell doesn’t have any friends?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE, (LESTER'S MOM)
dialogues.text: Not everyone was in the military, Butch. (to Peter) He and his pals take that whole Band of Brothers thing way too far.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What branch of the military were you in?

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Special Ops. Delta Force. Real covert shit.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I see. Well, thank you... for your service. Anyway, I just wanted to clear the air and apologize. It was really an honest mistake.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Apology accepted. Butch grunts. Peter looks at Lester, through the window.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can I ask... why do you think Lester was on that website?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: The same reason you were. He wanted to find a friend. Peter nods, clearly touched by this.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s a good kid, he’s just... a little different.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Let’s call it what it is. He’s a geek. Eleven years old, he dresses like Merlin the Magician.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: And we didn’t do him any favors with his name. The other children call him Lester the Molester.  57. Through the window, Peter eyes Lester practicing his swordplay. He’s actually kind of skillful.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You know, I’m a, uh, fencer. I’m in a club, it’s all legitimate. Maybe I could take Lester over there one day...

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Not happening.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Alright, I just thought he could maybe channel this sword and sorcery stuff into a sport. It’s in the Olympics. It’s very competitive.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: The school therapist did say he needs more social interaction...

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: You wear a goddamn mask when you fence. Who the hell’s he going to interact with?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Butch, it’s a surprisingly social sport. (hands them his card) Why don’t you think about it, give me a call if you change your mind. ON LESTER -- he looks at Peter, waves. Peter waves back. INT. PETER’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Peter holds Sydney’s business card. Clearly nervous. He takes a deep breath, dials.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, Sydney? It’s, uh, it’s The Pistol?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who?  58.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Peter... Klaven. From the Father's Office.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, man. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nothing, no, that was fun the other night. I’m just seeing if you wanted to get some lunch sometime. Just, super casual. But, if you don’t have time--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m about to take my Puggle for a jaunt on the Venice Boardwalk. Why don’t you join me for some eats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter joins Sydney as he walks his PUGGLE.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: He’s a cross between a Beagle and a Pug. Greatest dog in the world.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He’s really cute. What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Anwar Sadat. After Anwar Sadat. The former President of Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay. ‘Cause you were a big fan of his policies, or--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No, I was looking at an old issue of TIME magazine with Sadat on the cover when he was a puppy, it was uncanny how much they looked alike. Peter eyes Anwar Sadat, not quite seeing the resemblance.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, how’s Ferrigno coming? Any offers?  59.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not yet. This realtor I work with, Tevin Downey wants to share the listing with me.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: And split the commission? What about that land you want to develop?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, it would put a delay on that, but, I gotta sell this house. Tevin’s a total cheeseball, but, he markets himself like crazy, racks up a lot of sales.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: The guy sounds like a douche. Who needs him?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He says the listing is out of my league. Maybe he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Bullshit. That’s the insecurity talking. The way you set-up that Open House was understated, classy and elegant. Those sandwiches you put out were delicious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look, I’m definitely trying to sell the place, I just--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No, Pete, trying is having the intention to fail. You gotta scratch that word from your vocab. Say you'll do it. And you will. As Peter considers this, Anwar the Puggle squats down and poops. When he finishes, Sydney starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You need a plastic bag or--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Nah, I don’t pick up after my dog.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh. Isn’t it like a State Law--  60.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It’s a ridiculous rule. Dog poop is like compost. It has an enormous amount of nutrients that enrich the soil. Just then, a MALE JOGGER, steps in Anwar’s shit.

dialogues.speaker: MALE JOGGER
dialogues.text: Goddamnit! Clean up after your dog! And Sydney gets up right in his face.

dialogues.speaker: LUCKY TO STEP IN MY BEAUTIFUL
dialogues.text: PUGGLE’S SHIT! Spooked, the jogger runs away.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Sydney, what was that?!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (totally calm) I’m aman, Peter. I have an ocean of testosterone flowing through my veins. Society implores us to act civilized, keep everything under control. But, the fact is, we’re animals. And sometimes, we need to let it out. (then) Try it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Try what?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Scream. Come on, you're stressed about the Ferrigno house. I guarantee you’re anxious about your wedding in ways you’re not even aware of. Let it out, you’ll feel better.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t just scream in the middle of the Venice boardwalk.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Sydney are alone. Peter quietly screams.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Abh...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Okay, good. Now, gently remove your vagina and try it again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Aaahhh!!!

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE THE BOARDWALK
dialogues.text: We hear Peter scream louder. PEOPLE notice, concerned. Peter does it again -- with even more gusto. And as he finally lets out an incredible loud, guttural wail.... EXT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - LATER THAT DAY Establishing of a decent sized bungalow in Santa Monica. Sydney leads Peter across his small yard, towards a GARAG INT. SYDNEY’S GARAGE - CONTINUOUS The two men enter. Peter’s eyes widen as he takes in the leather couch, which sits in front of three large screen In a corner of the room there’s a music area with a drum kit, guitar, bass, tambourines. A bong sits on a trunk wh serves as a coffee-table. On the walls, dozens of PHOTOS Sydney with his GUY FRIENDS -- singing karaoke, white-wat rafting, at restaurants, at the Grand Canyon, etc.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Klaven, welcome to the Temple of Doom. Peter takes it in, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
