dialogues.text: Holy shit, Sydney. This place is insane. Peter spots a laz-e-boy recliner next to a side-table wit tube of Jergens and a box of CONDOMS.  62.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on over there?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (totally unembarrassed) Oh, that’s where I jerk off.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay, I see. And the condoms--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I wear them while I masturbate. It decreases sensitivity, so I can last longer, and also there’s no mess to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Uh, no, I’m absolutely serious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And... when women come over--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pistol, this is a man-cave. No woman has ever been granted access.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What about your guy friends? You're not embarrassed to have that out?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Masturbation is part of life. You’ve never talked about jerking off with any of your friends?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: When’s the last time you did it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m not telling you that.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of? I’m not going to tell anyone. Think of this place as a cone of silence.  Just then, 63.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Zooey went to the Pasadena Flea Market with her friends this weekend. I did it while she was out.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What’d you use? Internet? DVD?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s enough info for today.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: An old porno VHS tape?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I used a picture of Zooey ina bikini from this vacation we took to Cabo San Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You jerked off to a picture of your own girlfriend?! Are you sick?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (laughing) Why is that so wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pedro, it is wrong in so many ways, I can’t even begin to describe it. Peter’s cell-phone rings. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, honey. No, I’m over at Sydney’s house. Uh... nothing, we're just chilling. I guess I kind of played hooky this afternoon. Yeah, no, I‘ll see you at home later. Love you too, bye. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Why’d you tell her you bailed from work?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to lie to her. You’re one of the most honest people I’ve ever met, you can’t understand that?  64.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m honest with my friends. With women, it’s a whole different thing.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. There’s stuff you share with dudes you could never tell your girlfriend or wife.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I just don’t agree with that.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Okay, so, when you go home you’1l tell Zooey that you jerked off to her picture last weekend?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, but..

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: But, you just revealed that to me. Sydney shrugs. Outplayed, Peter’s got no response. He wal over to the cluster of MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS in the corner. There’s a poster for the band RUSH on the wall behind the drumset.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Which one do you play?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m a drummer. A stick-man. You play an instrument?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I played guitar in high school.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Oh, were you in a band?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No. I just played by myself. For fun. (then, eyeing the poster) Oh, man, I used to love RUSH.  65.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude! Best rock band in the world! Neil Peart, hands down, greatest stick-man who ever lived. We should jam sometime.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’d be fun, man. Alright, I should hit the road.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Coolio. I gotta get to bed early. I’m taking a day-hike in Malibu with some of my buddies tomorrow. Peter is clearly taken aback by this revelation.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, good. A buddies hike. That sounds fun.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (off Peter's vibe) You’re welcome to join us.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, no, thanks. I promised Zooey we'd deal with some wedding crap tomorrow. (like it’s ridiculous) Gotta get those “seating charts” figured out. (Sydney nods, doesn’t care) Alright, well, then, I‘1l, uh, I will see you...I will see you, uh, sometime soon. Good hang, Syd. Really fun hang. I'’11 see you.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Adios, Pistol.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Later-gater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter joins Robbie, who wears a league tee-shirt, inside this hip “bowling lounge.”  66.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m acting like a freak. He told me was going hiking with his friends and I got jealous! What am I supposed to do, tell him I want to be exclusive?!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You have a little man-crush, that’s all. Just make sure he’s not a friend slut.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Someone who’s constantly picking up new friends, dumping old ones. Like Lance Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why is Lance Armstrong a friend slut?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Because, every week there’s pictures of him in US Magazine working out with another guy. It’s Jake Gyllenhaal one day. Matthew McConaughey the next.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (then, noticing something) How long has dad been in your bowling league? PETER’S POV - OF THE LANES We now see that Oz wears a matching shirt. He bowls a strike, does a “crotch chop” a la professional bowler Pet Weber, and hi-fives several of Robbie’s GAY TEAMMATES.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: He started rolling with us a few months ago. The boys love him. Oz gives one of the TEAMMATES an encouraging slap on the

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I mean, it definitely seems like he likes me.  67.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: He sounds great. I just don’t want you to get hurt, that’s all. Peter eyes his brother appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thanks, Robbie. They’re interrupted by Oz and one of Robbie’s FLAMBOYANT BUDDIES doing a post-strike chant...

dialogues.speaker: OZ/FLAMBOYANT FRIEND
dialogues.text: The roof/The roof/The roof is on fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is at his desk when a RECEPTIONIST calls out...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Peter, I have Lou Ferrigno for you on line three. AT HIS DESK -- Tevin Downey quietly lifts up his receiver listens in on Pete’s conversation. BACK ON PETER - on the phone with Lou Ferrigno.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mr. Ferrigno? Peter Klaven. It’s nice to finally speak to you in person. As he listens to Ferrigno, Peter looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, could you speak a little slower. I’m just having trouble understanding you. Yes, sir, of course, I know you’re hearing impaired-- BY THE FRONT DOOR - Sydney Fife enters the office. The receptionist directs him towards Peter’s cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...if you’re saying that you’re concerned about the house, don’t worry. We’re holding another Open House this weekend.  68. Peter looks up, sees Sydney. Lights up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quietly, motions to phone) Ferrigno. (into phone) I think I understand. We’ll get it done. I promise. Goodbye. Peter hangs up. Highly stressed. Tevin puts down his receiver, scheming.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: The Hulk busting your balls?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I think so, it was kind of hard to tell. I’m not trying to be... it’s just, he’s hearing impaired, and he was on a cell. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: My sperm bank is a few blocks away on Westwood.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No, I deposit every couple of weeks. I may as well get paid for something I’m gonna do at home anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I want to argue with you about these things, but, you do make a certain kind of twisted sense.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I got some leftover Koo-Koo Roo at the house, you want to get some lunch, squeeze in a little jam session?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t, Syd. I gotta deal with this Ferrigno situation. Peter pops a Zantac.  69.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What do you have, acid reflux?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It comes and goes.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude, you’re not going to get anything done in this state. You need to get some grub and let out a little steam. I guarantee, you'll be more focused when you get back to the office. INT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - GARAGE - DAY CLOSE ON SYDNEY - sitting at his drum kit. He kicks out a beat. Then, in a blaring, Geddy Lee-style falsetto, he si the opening lyrics to the RUSH song “Tom Sawyer.”

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: A modern day warrior, Mean, mean stride, today’s Tom Sawyer, mean, mean pride! WIDER -- Peter has Sydney’s guitar slung around his neck. starts playing the ensuing chords...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though his mind is not for rent, Don't put him down as arrogant, His reserve, a quiet defense, Riding out the day's events... SYDNEY (CONT’D) PETER The river! The river! And as they jam, we begin a MONTAGE under the music...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Sydney walk Anwar Sadat. Sydney points out a DO OWNER who looks uncannily like his DOG.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I call them ‘Bowsers.’ It’s my nickname for people who look like their dogs.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ‘Bowsers?’ Where did you get that?  70.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Who knows? It just sounded right. A MUSCLE BEACH BODY BUILDER steps in Sadat’s poop. He confronts Sydney who starts screaming at him. A beat later, Sydney shouts ‘Run!’ And he and Peter take

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter shows Sydney his development site, explaining what plans to do with it. EXT. THE MARSH’S HOUSE - DAY Butch leads Lester to Peter, who waits in front of his ca Lester’s still wearing his wizard get-up. Butch whispers Peter's ear...

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: You try any molestation with my son, I’1l cut off your scrotum with a pearing knife. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (then, peppy, to Lester) Alright, Lester, you ready to do some fencing?! INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT The two of them sit at the dining room table, going over details for the wedding. Peter’s cell rings. It’s Sydney. He excuses himself, starts gabbing with his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter holds another Open House. Sydney emerges from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: This place is exquisite. I’d like to make an offer! Other prospective buyers take note.  71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes a hike with Sydney and his FRIENDS -- a diver group of guys. A CHUBBY FRIEND stops, out of breath. Sydn stops the group, helps his friend through some deep- breathing. Gives him some water. The friend recovers, thanks Sydney. Peter watches on, impressed at how caring Sydney is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter teaches Lester the basics of fencing. INT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - GARAGE - NIGHT The music continues... CLOSE ON A FRAMED TIME MAGAZINE COVER OF ANWAR SADAT. CLOSE ON SYDNEY'S PUGGLE. ON PETER - eyeing the magazine cover and the dog as he continues to jam with Sydney. ON SYDNEY - sweating profusely as he pounds away.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m doing it, man! I’m going full McConaughey! And Sydney rips his shirt off, his flabby stomach pulsati with the rhythm of his drumbeat. Peter cracks up, goes cr by unbuttoning the top two buttons of his dress-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER IS A FENCING PRODIGY.
dialogues.text: He and Peter engage in a tense match -- all that sword an sorcery stuff has clearly found its outlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Sydney cruise through Main Street in Santa Moni on Sydney’s VESPA. Peter notices a MAN who looks just lik his dog. He calls out...  72.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Bowser! Two O'clock Sydney sees him - the two friends crack up. INT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - GARAGE - NIGHT The song is reaching it’s climax. Sydney is now stripped down to his UNDERWEAR, sweating profusely as he screams i his off-key falsetto. Peter’s shirt is completely unbuttoned, while he jams out remaining bars to the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester DEFEATS Peter. He triumphantly whips off his mask, huge smile crossing his face. INT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - GARAGE - NIGHT And as Sydney stands up on his drum-seat, hits the symbol with his toe, before he LOSES HIS FOOTING and crashes int his KIT... we END THE MONTAGE. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT IN BED - Peter and Zooey flip through design magazines.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: .--he’s kind of got a point about Salman Rushdie. I’d never heard of him before that Iran thingie.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney’s theories are definitely out there, but he’s like this weird, street philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: He sounds really cool. When can I meet him?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I actually invited him to the engagement dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Wow, Peter, this is serious.  73.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s not. It’s totally mellow. He got divorced recently. I thought he and Hailey might hit it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing of this famous restaurant in the heart of L. Chinatown neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Klaven’s have taken over one of the restaurant’s smal BANQUET ROOMS for Peter and Zooey’s engagement party. Pet introduces Sydney around.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ...my brother, Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey! This is my date, Alan. Robbie introduces them to the MARRIED GUY from the gym.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And this is my fiance, Zooey Rice. Zo, this is Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Hi! I’ve heard so many nice things about you.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Same. Pete is like, absolutely ga- ga over you. It’s adorable. Zooey squeezes Peter’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: We feel really lucky. Zooey sees Hailey nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hailey, come meet Sydney. Hailey walks over.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sydney, this is Hailey. My oldest friend in the world.  74.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: How you doing? Hailey is overtly flirtatious in a faux-shy manner.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Really good, Sydney. So nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Ooh, there's Denise and Barry. Peter, come say hi. Zooey pulls Peter away, leaving Hailey and Sydney alone.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Barry and Peter are talking.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t remember, do you play an instrument, Barry? (points to Sydney) ‘Cause my friend, Syd, and I have been jamming a lot lately. He’ a stick-man and I wield the axe, so, it’s a good time.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t play an instrument, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, bummer. I was gonna invite you to hang with us, but, if you don’t play, it probably wouldn’t be fun.

dialogues.speaker: ON SYDNEY AND HAILEY
dialogues.text: Not hitting it off at all.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: How could you hate the Dalai Lama?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: He’s a phony. Always hanging out with Richard Gere. What is that? It’s not like he earned his title.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  75.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: He became the Dalai Lama when he was two years old. He didn’t win some kind of Dalai Lama election. He was a baby.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Well, I think he’s really inspirational.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Tell the truth, you just like him because he has a nice smile.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Okay, everyone! Dinner! Hailey glares at Sydney, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: BANQUET ROOM
dialogues.text: A group consisting of Peter’s parents, Sydney, and Zooey’ friends sit around a long dining table.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: ..-ever since Oswald got transferred to L.A., this has been Peter’s favorite restaurant. So, of course, he took Zooey here on their first date.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I only take the girls I really like to Yang Chow! Zooey playfully hits Peter. Joyce continues.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: True, true! But, I remember, when he got home that first night, he called me up and said, ‘Mom, I’m going to marry this girl. And it’s not just because she wanted an extra order of Slippery Shrimp!’ And, eight months later, here we are! Peter, Zooey, we're so happy for you. Cheers! Everyone toasts. They’re about to eat when Sydney stands clinks his fork against his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could just say a couple of words. 76. The guests look confused. Oz quietly turns to Joyce...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Be nice. He’s Peter’s new friend.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Zooey, I just want you to know, that, you are marrying one of the most honest, caring and fun loving men I’ve ever had the pleasure of knowing. Oz looks to Robbie, mouths, ‘Fun?’ Robbie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “The Pistol” is a pleasure-giver. The man lives to make other’s satisfied. But guys like that rarely ask for anything in return. So, as his friend, I’m here asking you, Zooey, give it back. Return the favor. And if you do, I guarantee, you’ll have a beautiful, and pleasure filled union. To Peter and Zooey. The confused guests clink glasses. Zooey looks to ‘What the hell did that mean?’

dialogues.speaker: BY THE LADIES ROOM
dialogues.text: Zooey walks to the bathroom by a WALL OF POLAROIDS eating at the restaurant. She takes them in, when catches her eye. It’s of PETER, smiling, with his an ATTRACTIVE WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: THE BANQUET ROOM
dialogues.text: Various family-style Chinese dishes line the table.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Sydney, what line of work are you in? Peter -- of guests one arm around  He exits. 77.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I do private investments, Oz. Manage my own money. I holda bunch of different market positions. Small Cap, Large Cap, a few foreign equities...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: What’d you do before you opened your own shop? Train at one of the big firms?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No-no, I never joined that rat- race. The idea of toiling like a sheep in the trenches of some faceless corp while the CEO and his buddies get rich never appealed.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oz was at IBM for thirty eight years.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I guess I was one of these sheep you're referring to.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Not at all, Oswald. I have a ton of respect for the company man. It’s just not the way I’m drawn. (stands up) ‘Scuse me, I just have to use the little cowboy’s room. People eat. Zooey turns to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Did you know there’s a picture of you and Lindsay up on the wall?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: There is? Oh, you know what, they took that a few years ago. I’1l ask Mr. Wong to take one of us.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t care. I was just, pointing it out. Oz shouts across the table to Peter...  78.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Private investments? What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dad, why do you have to be a jerk? He said he respects people who work for companies. It’s just not his thing.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: His thing?! Peter, you’ve known this yutz for three weeks and you’re acting like a bigger faggot than your brother. The guests look uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay, everyone, I gave him permission to use the “F” word. Dad, you might be abusing the privileges.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Really? Alright, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Well, I like him very much. He’s quite a unique individual. And he clearly adores Peter. Sydney reemerges with MR. WONG, the happy host.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I asked this dude to take a picture of you guys. Mr. Wong aims a Polaroid camera at Peter and Zooey.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WONG
dialogues.text: Smile, happy couple! Off his FLASH, we, go to... INT. PETER’'S CAR - NIGHT Peter and Zooey drive home. Zooey is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: What the hell did you tell Sydney about me?  79.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Uh, nothing. Aside from how much I love you.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Then, what was he talking about with all that pleasure-giver stuff?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I might have mentioned that, you know, you don’t love blowjobs.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Ew! Peter, that stuff is private.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, it is? Then, how come Hailey and Denise know every detail about our sex life?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: It’s totally different. I’ve known them forever. Sydney is practically a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, now you know how I feel when there’s no privacy with your girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I thought you liked those guys?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I love them, but, sometimes I just want things to be between you and me.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Fine. They drive for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not like I don’t like giving blowjobs. The thing is, Rodney hated getting them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What guy doesn’t like getting blowjobs?  80.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: He had this weird intimacy problem. It’s part of why we split up. So, I guess I just stopped doing it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: See? If Sydney hadn’t asked me about our sex life, we never would have talked about this.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I guess so. Still, it was a weird toast, and he also told Hailey that he hates the Dalai Lama.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He did? I love the Dalai Lama.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I know, he’s got such a cute smile. He’s like a Tibetan Teddy Bear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Peter heads to his desk, he passes Tevin Downey in his cubicle, practicing sign language as he reads a copy of SIGNING FOR DUMMIES. When he sees Peter, he tries to slid the book under some papers.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Uh-oh! There’s my dog!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How come you’re learning sign language?

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: My aunt is coming to town this weekend. She’s deaf, so, I want to brush up on a few phrases. Peter seems skeptical. He nods, walks away. PETER’S CUBICLE - MINUTES LATER Peter’s on the phone with Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Me too, Sydney. I’m really glad you came. I gotta say, Zooey was a little freaked out by your toast--  81.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Right, because I was pointing out the truth about something uncomfortable. One beej a month does not a marriage make, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, in the end, I think it led to a good talk, but--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cool. Glad I could help. What are you up to tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m having a date with Zooey.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay, well, cancel that ASAP, ‘cause I just got an e-mail alert from the FLY BY NIGHT ARMY.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Top secret RUSH fan-club. The holy trinity are playing a small club gig at THE MINT tonight. I have a friend who can get us tix.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That sounds fun, but, I kinda promised her I would--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have your entire life to have dinner with Zooey. This is a chance to get up close and personal with the greatest rock band in history.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I would like to check them out. Can I invite Zooey along?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Really?  82.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’d be a good chance for you guys to hang out, start off ona new foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUSH fans pour into this mid-sized L.A. rock club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure enough, RUSH plays in front of a small, packed crowd Peter, Sydney and Zooey are crushed between the masses, P and Sydney singing along with LIMELIGHT, while Zooey look absolutely miserable.

dialogues.speaker: PETER SYDNEY
dialogues.text: All the world’s indeed a All the world's indeed a stage, And we are merely stage, And we are merely Players, Peformers and Players, Peformers and Portrayers, Each another's Portrayers, Each another's audience, Outside the gilded audience, Outside the gilded cage! cage! Zooey looks at Peter like he is a complete stranger. He a Sydney are lost in the moment, making eye-contact, singin each other... Zooey is completely left out. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Zooey gets ready for bed. We can hear Peter on the phone his home office. Zooey quietly walks down the hall, sees Peter through the half-open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dude! I cannot believe they closed with SUBDIVISION! That was incredible... you’re right, Neil Peart is a god. Thanks for hooking that up, it was a great night. I’1ll talk to you tomorrow. (beat) Love you too, man. G’night. Zooey is completely shocked that she just heard Peter tel Sydney he loves him. Peter opens the door, catches Zooey standing there.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were you spying on me?  83.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You told Sydney you loved him?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I said goodnight, I don’t remember what I said.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter, what is up with you two? We're supposed to have a date, but, instead, you drag me to this concert. You don’t say one word to me the whole night. You come home and immediately get on the phone with the guy. Are you in love with him?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of course not. Zooey, you said you didn’t want me to be your best friend, so, I went out and found one. And you know what, it’s great! I did it for you at first, but, I had no idea what I was missing. Do you know that I haven’t taken a Zantac in three weeks? It’s because there’s all this stuff I was keeping inside that I can finally talk about.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: That’s great, but, it doesn’t mean you can’t share things with me. I feel like I’m losing you a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’re not. I promise. I love you. I just, like having a friend, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Okay. He kisses her. Things are heating up, when... Peter’s cel phone rings. He eyes the Caller I.D..

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I have to take this.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Is that Sydney again?  84.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s Lester. He should be in bed, I wonder why he’s calling so late.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Lester? The kid you met on the internet? You’re still seeing him?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I thought I told you, I’m teaching him to fence.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: No, you didn’t tell me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (answers phone) Lester? What’s going on? Right, Kim Little, the girl from your Social Studies class. What happened? Zooey starts to walk away, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: And I liked some of those RUSH songs. Not that you ever looked at me to notice. She exits, leaving Peter on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Sydney stroll through the formalwear department

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: So, the big day is coming up. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was feeling good, but, Zooey and I have been fighting a lot in the past couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Why are you marrying her? Peter stops walking, faces Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that?  85.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It seems like you’ve been in one relationship after another. Is Zooey the one, or is she just the next one?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, she’s the one.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Because, I don’t know, we’re in love and... that’s a hard question to answer.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to push you, I’m genuinely curious. Come on, let’s try on penguin suits. FORMALWEAR DEPARTMENT - MEN’S DRESSING ROOM Sydney talks to Peter behind the dressing room door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m thinking about asking Tevin if he wants in on the Ferrigno house.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude, I saw that guy’s face on a bus-stop ad. You do not need to split the commission with that frosted hair jag-off. Peter walks out, wearing a nice, conservative tux.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I have to face facts, Syd, I’ma flats guy. Tevin’s got the flash needed to sell the place. (re: the tux) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Turn around, let me see the back. Peter turns around. Syd stands up, starts touching the fabric around Peter's shoulders  86.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a bit conservative and I’m not in love with the drape. I’d like to see you in something with some flare, peacock it out a little. Sydney hands Peter a tux -- flashy, but cool-looking.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, give this one a shot.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: There is no freaking way I can pull this off.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You have this image of yourself as this tight, by-the-book guy, but, I’ve seen you let loose in the Temple of Doom. It’s the same thing with the Ferrigno house -- you have the skills, you just don’t have the confidence. Try it on. Peter reluctantly heads back into the dressing room with new tux. As he and Syd talk, we INTERCUT between dressing room and waiting area.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, so, I wanted to talk to you about something. I have an investment opportunity, it’s a complete winner, but, the problem is all my funds are tied up in equities, so, I’m cash poor right now.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’ve got a bit of a liquidity problem, so, I wanted to know if you would consider loaning me a few sheckles. I’d pay you back, of course, with interest.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How much money are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I'd need like, five.  87. Peter exits the dressing room in his flashy tux.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Five thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude! That looks great!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It does?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Don’t forget, Zooey’s artsy. She’s gonna love that. You're like a confident, sexy peacock.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Five thousand is a lot of money. Zooey’s not really close with her family, so, we’re paying for the wedding--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pete, enough said. An opportunity came up, thought I’d ask--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can you tell me about the investment?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I actually can’t. It’s confidential in nature.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, let me think about it. Just then, DOUG, the attractive guy who kissed Peter on t man-date spots him.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hello, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doug, hi, how are you? Awkward beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You know, it takes a lot of nerve to spend a beautiful evening with someone, and never call them again.  88.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doug, let me explain, I-- Doug eyes Sydney -- assuming they’re together.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I get it, Peter. I just wish I could take back that kiss, because, I felt something I hadn’t felt in years, and, now, I realize, it was the taste of betrayal.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It wasn’t the taste of betrayal! And Doug storms off. Peter turns to Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can actually explain what just happened there. EXT. “THE GROVE” — DAY Peter and Sydney stroll through this outdoor shopping mal Peter holds a Neiman Marcus bag with his new tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: From the engagement party, I figured you didn’t have a ton of friends, but, I didn’t know it went that far.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Either did I. The truth is, it was never an issue until we got engaged.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Wait, so, you were using me because Zooey wanted you to have a Best Man.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dude, no, that’s not it at all. I had actually given up on meeting someone. Then, you came into that Open House, we hit it off, and, one thing led to the next.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I just wish you had told me.  89.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was embarrassed. Look, you have a million friends--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Who are pissed at me ‘cause I've been spending so much time with you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: They’re like a bunch of teenage girls. They'll be fine. Look, I just want you to know, you can tell me anything.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I really appreciate that, man. (stops, turns to Syd) So, listen, about that investment--—

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pete, forget I even mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I’ve been saving my whole life, plus, you're right, I’m gonna sell the Ferrigno house. I’m happy to loan you the money. I know you’re good for it.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Really?! Pistol, that’s great!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s the least I can do for the Best Man at my wedding.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I want you to stand up there with me. Are you cool with that? Sydney looks like he’s going to cry.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Of course I'll be your Best Man. It would be my honor.  90. And Sydney reaches out and gives Peter a warm hug. Unused this intimacy, Peter pats him on the back, the way most m do when they hug.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sh-sh-sh, no patting, brother. When you give a real hug you don’t pat -- you just hold on and feel the friendship. Peter does. It’s different. More intimate. OZ AND ROBBIE exit the movie theater at the Grove. They stop in their tracks, as they spot Peter and Sydney holding each other.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh. My. God.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I know you took away my permission, but I’m sorry, those two are a couple of tushy twins. And then, Doug walks by, shaking his head as he watches P and Sydney’s PDA...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Uch. Fucking whore. .».-only adding to Oz and Robbie’s confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Lester have their masks off as they casually pa with each other.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s right here in L.A., it’s like the biggest junior fencing competition in the country. I say we give it a shot.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: You think I’m good enough?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dude, you’re gonna kick those other kids’ butts.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I don’t really want to do that, Peter. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want to engage ina gentlemanly contest and let the best fencer win.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of course. You can do that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Lester change into their street clothes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So how’s it going with that girl? What’s her name? Kim Little?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I asked her to coffee, she said she’d never date any one named Lester the Molester. I think she’s sleeping with Sam Krickstein anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Lester, she’s eleven. I guarantee you she’s not sleeping with Sam Krickstein.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Making love... whatever. They’re definitely linked romantically. Lester puts on his wizard’s hat and Harry Potter glasses. Peter watches -- considering something.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Buddy, let me throw something out here. I’m thinking the glasses and hat might be getting in the way of your social life.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, they make a statement. And it’s not a bad statement. It shows you’re into magic and sorcery and whatnot, but, I kind of feel like you’re a cool dude on your own. You don’t need the costume to prove it.  92.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: You’re saying I should go without the hat and glasses?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m saying try it. See how you feel. Lester considers this for a long beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: You may just have a point, Peter. INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT The two of them sit around the kitchen table with pieces paper related to their wedding plans.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: So, if Hailey doesn't bring the strap-on guy, which is pretty likely, we’ll have an empty seat at our table.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Actually, I was thinking Sydney might sit with us.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I asked him to be my Best Man. Beat. Zooey takes this in. Then...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, are you happy about that? Bummed? Give me something other than, ‘Okay.’

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I feel like he has some issue with me -- maybe I’m crazy, but that’s the vibe I get.  93.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s the case. You guys just haven’t spent that much time together. But, I’1l talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter, no, don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Because, then he’s going to think I’m saying shit about him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But you are saying shit about him.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: That’s not the point. I don’t want you to say anything. Please.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: (back to the wedding stuff) Alright, so, we still need to pick up the marriage license. Can you do it at lunch tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, I mean, I can move some stuff around.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Well, do you have a meeting or something?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I was just gonna meet up with Sydney. It’s fine, I'll move it.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: We can make it after lunch if that’s better.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay, yeah. What about two O’clock at the Marriage Bureau?  94.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m excited. It’s becoming so official! Zooey smiles weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Sydney eat gyros while they walk Anwar Sadat. LANCE ARMSTRONG and VIN DIESEL roller-blade past them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fucking Lance Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: So, what did Zooey say about me being your Best Man?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She, was uh, she was cool about it.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Dude, come on, your voice went up when you said that.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fuck. I’m the worst liar. I promised her I wouldn't say anything, but, she feels like you haven’t made an effort with her.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pete, Zooey seems like a great girl, but, the fact is, she’s not my friend. You are, and, to that end, I’m there for you, 100 percent. It’s bro's before ho’s’ with me. Some women have a problem with that, but, that’s just the way it is.  95.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is that why your marriage broke up?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sure, it was a contributing factor. Across the way, something catches Peter’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I knew that’s why he was learning sign language. Peter’s POV -- at a boardwalk restaurant, Tevin Downey is having lunch with the incredibly muscular LOU FERRIGNO. Too late.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Is that Downey? We gotta confront them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Syd, no, let me think for second. Sydney is on the move, storming up to their table.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you’re doing?!

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No, but I believe you know my friend, Peter Klaven, who has the exclusive on this man’s property! Peter walks up to them.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Hey, Peter. You know Lou Ferrigno, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, hi, Mr. Ferrigno. How do you two know each other?

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: I reached out to Lou, ‘cause, I’m organizing a fund-raiser for hearing impaired athletes. It’s a cause that’s near and dear to me.  96.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: That is total crap, you cheeseball! Lou, you gave Peter the listing on the house...

dialogues.speaker: LOU FERRIGNO
dialogues.text: I know, and he’s not doing shit with it!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: That’s bullshit, Hulk! He’s setting the table, lining up some serious buyers. This stuff doesn’t happen overnight.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: Peter, who the hell is this guy?!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Am I talking to you, Hi-Lites? I don’t think so. Look, Hulk--

dialogues.speaker: LOU FERRIGNO
dialogues.text: Please get your hand out of my face and stop calling me Hulk. I’ma person, okay?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (getting really worked up) You’re a person?! So is Peter Klaven! He’s busted his dick trying to sell your house, and you double-cross him with this Redondo Beach douchebag!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Hulk! Sydney throws a punch at Lou Ferrigno who dodges it, with very little effort, grabs Sydney, putting him into a slee hold, as he gently eases him onto the ground. As Sydney futilely fights back--

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Easy, easy, don’t fight it. Peter’s cell-phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hello?!  97.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m just checking in. I’m on my way to the Marriage Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Ahhh!!! Get the fuck off of me!!!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that Sydney?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, he got in a fight with Lou Ferrigno--

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He what?! What is going on?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Zooey, I don’t think I can make it. I’m really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How could you not make it?! Peter---

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Zo, I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: He’s choking me! The Hulk is choking me! INT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - NIGHT They stand in the kitchen. Zooey is dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Why would anyone get in a fight with Lou Ferrigno?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney’s a hot-head. He thought he was standing up for me.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: So did you lose the listing?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I believe I did.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: And what does that mean for your development property?  98.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I probably have to let it go. I was counting on the commission for the down payment.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You have some money saved up. Can’t you write them a check, you know, to show your good faith.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No. Between the wedding, and, then I lent Sydney some money, I’m just a little short.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Wait-wait, you lent Sydney money?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: For an investment. All his money was tied up in equities, so... I mean, he’s going to pay me back.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Peter, that’s not the point. We’re getting married. You can’t keep that kind of stuff from me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? Why do you think we’re getting married?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney asked me the question, you know, ‘Why Zooey?’ And I... of course I love you, but, I’m not exactly sure how to answer that.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Two weeks, before our wedding you’re asking me why we're getting married?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I... it just came up. Okay? Forget I even asked.  99.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You know, Peter, in my opinion, that’s the kind of thing you figure out with your friends, not your fiance. (anger building) So, I am going to stay with Denise and Barry, and you and your pal Sydney can hang out, and go to RUSH concerts, and fight Lew Ferrigno, while you try to answer the question of why the hell you proposed to me after only eight months of dating. Okay?! Goodbye! She exits, SLAMMING the door behind her. PETER’S HOME OFFICE - LATER THAT NIGHT Peter’s on the phone with Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This is good? How is this good, Sydney? SYDNEY’S GARAGE - CONTINUOUS (INTERCUT CONVERSATION)

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Because, Pistol, you need to be sure. This will give you some space to think about what you’re doing. I’m going to Joshua Tree with some of my buddies for the weekend. Why don’t you come with?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said?! Zooey walked out on me! How can I think about taking a male-bonding weekend trip?! And also, why do all you guys always go to Joshua Tree?!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Peter, in times of stress, your guy friends are who you can count on. This is exactly the time for you to be doing that. Alright, Seinfeld’s on Letterman. I gotta go. G’night.  100. Peter hangs up, looks out the window. His neighbor is now sharing an INTIMATE ROMANTIC DINNER with a date. They lau then, he kisses her. Peter looks troubled. His phone ring He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, Lester. Yes, tomorrow afternoon. I’11 pick you up. What? No, I’m fine. Nothing. Just some stuff with Zooey. I’11 see you tomorrow. EXT. PETER AND ZOOEY’S HOUSE - MORNING Peter looks like crap as he walks towards his car. INT./EXT. PETER’S CAR - MORNING He drives to work when something catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh my god. PETER’S P.O.V. -- there is a huge BILLBOARD of Peter, a l James Bond in a tuxedo, pointing a gun at the lens. A sig beneath reads: “PETER KLAVEN. LICENSE TO SELL.” At the bottom, his office number at Remax Realty. Peter turns a corner -- sees ANOTHER BILLBOARD with his likeness. This time, he’s in a suit, with Ray-Ban sunglas tipped onto his nose, like a poster for a cheesy 80s movi The slogan reads: “PETER KLAVEN. THE MARKET’S SO BRIGHT, HE'S GOTTA WEAR SHADES.”

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. My goddd! Peter turns into his office parking lot. Right across the street, another billboard. In this one, he’s dressed as a COWBOY, (with a thick moustache) -- photo-shopped in fron an Olde West Street. The slogan reads: “PISTOL” PETE KLAV THE FASTEST REALTOR IN THE WEST.”

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. My. Gooooddd!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Peter enters, his co-workers, who have clearly been talking about his billboards, pretend to go back to work.  101. He heads to his desk, mortified. The older female co-work walks by. She’s being genuine...

dialogues.speaker: OLDER FEMALE CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Very creative advertising. He nods, then makes eye-contact with Tevin Downey, who mockingly pretends to shoot a gun in his direction. EXT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - DAY Peter’s car screeches to a halt in front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: Peter bangs on the door to the man-cave. Sydney opens

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s what you spent my five thousand dollars on?!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You saw the billboards?! Pretty awesome, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Pretty awesome?! “The Fastest Realtor In The West?!” “The Market’s So Bright, He’s Gotta Wear Shades?!” They’re idiotic! I’1l be the laughing stock of the entire real estate industry!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You know what, man, I was trying to help, okay? That douchebag Downey has bench ads over the entire West Side. You need this kind of stuff to get a leg up on the competition.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look, I appreciate the gesture, but, why didn’t you just tell me?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Because, I know you, Pistol. I knew you’d react exactly the way you’re doing now. So, I figured I’d take matters into my own hands. it.  102.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney, in one day you’ve screwed up my career, ruined my relationship--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: By doing what?! Asking why you wanted to marry Zooey? That’s what men do for each other.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I am so goddamn sick of your ridiculous codes! ‘You can’t tell women this.’ ‘It’s bro’s before ho’s.’ Sydney, I like sharing stuff with Zooey. I like spending time just hanging out with her. You know that my favorite night in the last five years is when she and I stayed home, made a summer salad, and watched CHOCOLAT together. And it was my pick at Blockbuster!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: CHOCOLAT? That is just... I don’t even know where to begin. Beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look, I think we need some time apart.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Us. This. Whatever it is we’re doing here. It’s not working out.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You know what, man, I have to agree.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right, so, I think it’s probably best, that, uh... if I do actually have a wedding... (this is hard for him) ...that you not be there.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sounds good to me.  103.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And, if you could have those billboards taken down--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Will do. And I'll get you that five grand next week.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No rush. Oh, and I think you have my season two LOST dvd’s. I mean, if you haven’t watched them, you could just--

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It’s okay, man. Here you go. Sydney picks up the box-set of LOST, hands it to Peter. T two men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish you the best of luck, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You too, Sydney. (as he leaves) Why would you hate the Dalai Lama? He’s absolutely adorable and he stands for peace. And Peter exits. EXT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Peter heads to his car, passing Sydney’s FRIENDS, who hav just pulled up in a VAN, ready for their weekend away.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He’s all yours, guys. They look confused as Peter gets in his car, speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A major Junior fencing competition is taking place. Peter stands near the “STRIP” (the fencing area) with Lester, w about to go on. Peter seems really wound up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How you doing, Lester? You nervous?  104.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Not really. I feel a strong sense of inner peace.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Alright, good. ‘Cause I feel like I’m gonna throw up.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Hey, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I’m really glad you’re my friend. Peter’s clearly touched. An ANNOUNCER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: You ready, son?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The announcer speaks into a mic.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And now, for the final match of the Los Angeles County Junior Fencing Competition, from Riverside, we have Aaron Lieberman. And from Glendale, we have Lester, the uh... (confused, as he reads from a piece of paper) ...Lester “The Molester” Marsh. Owning the nickname, Lester raises his hand, as he acknowledges the small crowd. The two fencers salute each other, as we go into SLOW MOT Lester is incredible. Graceful. Confident. Totally in control. Peter cheers on his protege. The crowd grows as word of an incredible fencer spreads throughout the arena. The referee continues awarding Lester points. And, after closing with a flourish, the match ends. The referee raises Lester’s hand in triumph.  105. Lester removes his helmet, as a huge smile crosses his fa The crowd cheers. He gentlemanly bows to his opponent and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: END SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: Peter runs up to Lester.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dude! That was incredible!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: It was an excellent match. My opponent was very skilled, but, I think I got the better of him. Then, a CUTE GIRL, 12, dressed in fencing gear, approache

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GIRL
dialogues.text: Mr. Marsh? I’m Kira. I fence in the Van Nuys club. Would you like to parry with me sometime?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I would very much like that, me- lady.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GIRL
dialogues.text: Okay, cool. Here’s my e-mail. She hands him a piece of paper with her info, walks away. Lester turns to Peter, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You got digits!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I know! How awesome is that! They try to hi-five, but end up missing each other’s hand

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We'll get that next time. Come on, I’m taking you out to celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Lester eat Chinese food.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: -».so, if you and that fencing girl hit it off, you need to figure out a place to take her for a date.  106.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Like my room?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, somewhere public, like a restaurant, or Pinkberry. One of the reasons I like to come here with women is they know me. I’m familiar with the menu. I’m comfortable here. Dating is stressful enough, you want to try to control your environment as much as possible.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: You really know a lot about girls.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Girls I’m pretty good at. Guys, not so much. I gotta run to the bathroom, I’1l be right back. BY THE MEN’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Peter waits for the Men’s Room to open up. As he does, he eyes the WALL OF PHOTOS. The Polaroid of him and Lindsay still up. But next to it is a new photo, taken the night the engagement party, of Peter and Zooey -- looking happy in love. MR. WONG, the owner of the restaurant, approaches. He poi to the new photo..

dialogues.speaker: MR. WONG
dialogues.text: Came out nice, right? Where’s your beautiful fiance?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, Mr. Wong. Yeah, she, uh, she couldn’t make it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WONG
dialogues.text: You are lying.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How the hell did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WONG
dialogues.text: You’re voice got high, like a girl. I’m not worried about you, Peter. You’1l bring a new one in here soon enough.  107. He pats Peter on the shoulder, exits. Peter takes this in then, he turns, looks again at the photos of him with Lin and Zooey. He turns his attention across the restaurant t Lester, happily eating a moo-shoo pancake, as we go...

dialogues.speaker: A HAND RINGING A DOOR-BELL
dialogues.text: EXT. BARRY AND DENISE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Denise opens the door, revealing Peter standing outside. the b.g., Barry and his friends are playing poker.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Nice billboards. I’11 get Zooey. Denise exits. Peter makes eye-contact with Barry and his FRIENDS, who do not look happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (calling out) I can’t stay. Just came to talk to my fiance. Zooey approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: “License to Sell?”

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know. That’s what Sydney did with the five grand I lent him. He thought they’d be good for my career.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: They definitely get your name out there. And you look kind of cute with a thick moustache.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Zooey, I know why I want to marry you.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I’m all ears.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The truth is, I have been a girlfriend guy, but, you’re the first woman I’ve ever been with who really wants me to have my own life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to come clean, I heard you talking about me at that ladies night a couple months ago.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Of course you did. It was totally obvious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, well, I thought you wanted me to have friends for you, but, I’m pretty positive you actually wanted that for me. And, that’s one of the most romantic things I can ever imagine. So, can we get this engagement back on track.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Yes. I hate it here. Barry and his friends are awful.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: By the way, I ended things with Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Really? Peter, I hope you didn’t do that for me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn’t. He can be a great guy, but, it just wasn’t working out. And we FADE UP a slow, acoustic version of the classic Qu song, “You’re My Best Friend,” over the following: EXT. PETER’S CAR - DAY He drives past his development site near downtown L.A., clearly upset that it is now out of his reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney walks Anwar Sadat alone. The dog poops. He walks away. A WOMAN screams at him but Sydney just keeps walkin doesn’t have the energy to scream back at her.  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Zooey walk hand in hand on jogging path, engros in conversation -- connecting again. A WOMAN jogs by -- s looks exactly like her DOG. Peter points her out to Zooey...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Check it out... she’s a Bowser. She looks exactly like her dog.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I don’t really see it. Peter is clearly disappointed... INT. SYDNEY’S HOUSE - GARAGE - NIGHT Sydney puts his Jergens and condoms from his jerk-off are into a drawer. He looks longingly at the music area, focusing in on the guitar Peter used to play. INT./EXT. PETER’S CAR - DAY As Peter drives to work, he looks up, catches one of his billboards. Shakes his head. But on his face, it’s clear he’s starting to see the humor in it. EXT. SYDNEY’S VESPA - DAY While he drives, he looks up at another “PETER KLAVEN” billboard. Clearly thinking about his friend. And we END THE SONG as the montage comes to a close...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters the office. The RECEPTIONIST greets him.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Peter, where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, my wedding’s this weekend, we had to do some preparation.  110.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Alright, well, check your voice- mail. You have like a million messages. Off Peter’s confusion...

dialogues.speaker: PETER CUBICLE
dialogues.text: He picks up the phone, dials his voice-mail. In a SERIES CUTS, we hear various prospective BUYERS AND SELLERS... Then..

dialogues.speaker: BUYERS AND SELLERS
dialogues.text: ‘Is this Pistol Pete? I have a home in Los Feliz I’ve been trying to sell...’ ‘Hi, I’m calling for the James Bond of Real Estate. I saw the Ferrigno Estate online and, I’ve lot to take a look at it.’ ‘I’m looking for a property in Bel Air.’ ‘The market’s so bright... that’s hysterical. Call me.’

dialogues.speaker: LOU FERRIGNO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter, hi, it’s Lou Ferrigno. Great freakin’ billboards! I’m sorry I doubted you, man. I told that douchebag Tevin, I want you to have the exclusive back, so, if you can forgive and forget, please give me a call. Oh, and I have a signed HULK poster for your friend. I hope his neck is okay. Thanks, Peter. Or, should I say, “Pistol Pete.” Call me. Peter looks out the window, where one of Sydney’s billboa is mounted. He clearly can’t believe it. Tevin Downey approaches from the back, starts tickling Peter.

dialogues.speaker: TEVIN
dialogues.text: There’s my Dog! (Peter pushes him away) Me likey the billboards. I underestimated you, my brother. What say we go to Houston's, grab a burger and a beer and figure out how we can tag-team this Ferrigno thing.  111.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You know what, Tevin. I would never go for a beer with you. Because I only do that with my friends. And you, sir, have no idea what it means to be a friend. Now if you’1l excuse me, I have to go to my wedding. And also, the next time you tickle me, I’m gonna punch you in the fucking face, Dog! And a proud Peter exits the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing of this beautiful hotel overlooking the paci just outside of Santa Barbara, California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is getting ready in the bedroom, while Oz and Robbi watch a televised GOLF TOURNAMENT in the living room. Peter puts on the flashy tux he bought with Sydney. Walks out to show it to the guys.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Looking good, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (re: the golf) Get in the hole!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So, any words of wisdom Dad? It’s clear Oz and Robbie are totally focused on the golf.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You’1l be fine.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Really? No insights about the fact that I’1l be sleeping with the same women for the rest of my life?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: To be honest, I really try not to think about that Peter.  112.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You know I have nothing to add. ON THE TV - Tiger Woods putts.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Get legs!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I would totally fuck Tiger Woods.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I don’t blame you. He’s buff as hell. He’d give you the ride of your life.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Guys, I’m getting married in an hour and you two are my groomsmen. I mean, come on, give me something.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: It’s the back nine at the U.S. OPEN, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right, that is important. Okay, I’m gonna take a walk. Peter leaves the two of them alone. Oz turns to Robbie...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You wear condoms when you do it with all those guys, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Every time.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Good. They exchange a nice father/son look. Then...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (re: Tiger Woods) Ooh. I think I saw the outline of his dick in his pants. INT. CAR — DAY ON THE PASSENGER SEAT - an audio-book of the Dalai Lama’s ART OF HAPPINESS.  113. A narrator reads the book over the car’s speakers. A CELL-PHONE rings. CLOSE ON SYDNEY, driving, as he picks it up. We hear his side of the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Hello? Wow, I did not expect to hear from you. You sure it’s a good idea, I mean, it’s your wedding? I don’t want to impose. Alright, well, if I hurry, I might be able to make part of it. I know, I’m sorry too. Hey... I’m really glad you called. Bye-bye. SLIGHTLY WIDER -- we now see that Sydney is wearing a TUX OUTSIDE THE CAR - Sydney’s rental GEO METRO passes a sign which reads: SANTA BARBARA - 10 MILES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zooey emerges from the bedroom in a bathrobe -- Hailey an Denise are getting ready in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Zo, this is ridiculous. Who’s it gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’ve thought a lot about this. You're right, I do have a best friend.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Is it Hailey? I knew it! You know what, that’s great. Seriously. I get it, you’ve known her longer.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Are you serious? It’s me?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Would you shut up? It’s not you.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Guys, it’s Peter, okay? Peter is my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Peter is your best friend?

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: I thought you were skeeved out by that idea.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Iwas. But, then I thought about it and... look, I love you guys... you know that, but, Peter’s about to be my husband. He understands me more than anyone else in the world. So, that’s it. He’s my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: That is so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: You still have to pick a Maid of Honor.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I love you both equally. You’re going to have to share the job.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: I love you so much, Zooey.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: I love you too, but, honestly, I’m a little bummed. I thought you were going to pick me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BY THE BEACH -- EIGHTY guests have now taken their seats. Amongst them -- Peter’s FENCING BUDDIES, the older female real estate agent and her husband, the OLD MAN Peter went a man-date with, Lester’s parents, and his gay date, DOUG Peter stands by the altar, with his GROOMSMEN, Oz, Robbie and LESTER. Oz leans over, whispers in his son’s ear...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m sorry I wasn’t there for you more when you were a kid.  115.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s okay, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You just always seemed like you had your shit together. What’d you first get laid when you were ten?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Still... not bad. You turned out good, Peter. I’m proud of you. Oz warmly rubs his son’s shoulder. Robbie leans over.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Great. I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It’s been fun getting to know you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You too, Robbie. Robbie takes Peter’s hand, sweetly squeezes it.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Guys, we’re at a wedding, we gotta stop acting like a bunch of homos.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Peter, en garde! Here she comes! Music plays, and a beaming, beautiful Zooey heads down th aisle, followed by Hailey and Denise. The JUSTICE OF THE PEACE whispers to Peter...

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but whose got the ring? Peter eyes his groomsmen, then responds...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t really have a Best Man, so, I‘1l just hold onto it.  116. As Zooey approaches the altar, she takes in Peter’s outfi nods her head, psyched.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Awesome tux. She stands across from Peter, Denise and Hailey by her si along with a long row of BRIDESMAIDS.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. We are gathered here today in this beautiful place, to join together Peter Klaven and Zooey Rice in matrimony. If anyone can show just cause why they may not be married, let them speak now, or forever hold their peace. Beat. Then, from behind the guests, SYDNEY FIFE emerges.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. All the guests turn their heads.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t object. Seriously. I’m all for it. Continue. Zooey turns back to Peter, smiles at him...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You invited him?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t let you get married without your Best Man.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I love you too. They’re about to kiss, when...

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
dialogues.text: Wait! We haven’t even done the ceremony!  117.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right, sorry. Sydney, come on up here. He does. Taking his place next to Peter, who hands him hi RING BOX, whispers...

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about all the stuff I said.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Me too, man. (beat) Oh, dude, I rented CHOCOLAT. (then) Just... delightful. The two friends exchange a quick laugh as the Justice continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocktail hour. A BAND plays. Guests mingle. Robbie and Doug are hitting it off. IN ANOTHER CORNER, Sydney walks up to Hailey.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Hey. They stand there for a beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I was wrong about the Dalai Lama. He’s an amazing guy.

dialogues.speaker: HAILEY
dialogues.text: Really? Because, I don’t actually know anything about him. You were right, I just like his smile. ACROSS THE WAY, Peter and Zooey watch them interact -- th laugh, hitting it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened? I thought you couldn’t stand him.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: The more I thought about it, the more I realized he did what a great friend is supposed to do. He asked you the really tough questions, and I’m pretty sure he did it because he cares about you. (off Peter's nod) Plus, you seemed really sad when I didn’t get that whole Bowser thing. Sydney approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Thanks for calling, Zooey.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: I was worried you wouldn’t get here in time.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Well, there was no traffic and I’m a pretty fast driver, so--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dude, you’re lying. Your voice when up when you said that.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I was five minutes away when Zooey called. I love you, man. Invite or not, there was no way I was gonna miss your wedding. And also, I wanted to give you this. Sydney hands Peter a check for FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sydney, you don’t need to do this.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Pistol, I know you don’t believe this, but, I’m actually a pretty successful investor. I told you, I just had a liquidity problem. The billboards were a gift. 118.  119.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh my god, they worked! We have an offer on Ferrigno. My development site is back on.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: That’s great, Pete. I’m happy for you. A bridesmaid motions for Zooey to come over and say hi. Before she walks away...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Oh, and, for the record, Sydney, I do like giving blowjobs. I just got out of the habit. But, thanks for looking out for your buddy here.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’ve learned more about how to treat women from this guy than any friend I’ve ever had. The least I can do is make sure he’s getting bj’s on a regular basis.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I am just incredibly uncomfortable with the conversation you two are having.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: Why? We’re all friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guests are seated at tables as the meal is served. The ba plays. Peter walks up to the bandstand, whispers to the BANDLEADER, who hands him the mic and motions for the musicians to stop playing.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hi, everyone. Thank you all so much for being here. Since getting engaged to Zooey Rice, I’ve learned a lot about myself, about relationships, and about friendships. Zooey, I know you don’t like me to say this, but, I don’t care. You’re my best friend, and I hope that never changes.  120. ON ZOOEY - tearing up. She quietly replies...

dialogues.speaker: ZOOEY
dialogues.text: You’re my best friend too, Peter. Denise and Hailey exchange a look. They have to accept it

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: There are just a few people here I want to mention specifically. First off, my younger brother Robbie. We haven’t been close our whole lives, but, these past few months, he’s helped me in ways I could never imagine. So, Robbie, here’s to you. (looks around) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I think he’s banging the caterer. Doug drops his head, bummed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Well, I'll just convey that to him in private. Anyway, Mom, Dad, Lester, Hailey, Denise, you guys have all been there for me as well, and I thank you for that. But most of all, I want to thank someone who taught me the true meaning of friendship. Sydney Fife, I love you, man. Peter walks up to Sydney, and the two men hug. No patting And as they hold on to each other, Joyce turns to Oz...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I’m not saying a word. And as CREDITS ROLL...

dialogues.speaker: A GUITAR
dialogues.text: as Peter plays the driving opening notes to RUSH’S LIMELI WIDER -- Sydney is behind the drum-kit He joins in on the beat -- a headset mic strapped to his face, as he begins singing in his not-so-beautiful falsetto...  121. The rest of the band joins in, and the guests start to da As the music continues, Sydney RIPS his shirt off...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m doing it, man! I’m going full McConaughey! Peter cracks up, looks to Zooey -- her face a combination shock and delight. And as he unbuttons the top couple of buttons on his shirt, and the music continues, we...
